description:
Deilephila porcellus, commonly known as the small elephant hawk-moth, is a species of moth belonging to the family Sphingidae. It is a small to medium-sized hawk-moth with a distinctive coloration and patterning.

The wingspan of Deilephila porcellus typically ranges from 45 to 55 millimeters. The forewings are grayish-brown with a pinkish-brown tinge and have a series of dark, wavy lines running across them. The hindwings are bright pink, with a dark band near the outer edge.

The caterpillars of Deilephila porcellus are also distinctive, with a large, eye-like spot on the thorax and a tapering, trunk-like head, which gives them a resemblance to small elephants, hence the common name. The caterpillars feed on various species of willowherb (Epilobium) and bedstraw (Galium).

Deilephila porcellus is widely distributed across Europe and parts of Asia, and it is commonly found in habitats such as woodlands, gardens, and urban areas where its host plants are present. The species undergoes a single generation per year, with adults typically flying from May to August.
